2.15.19  3:48 am   2.12.19  3:59 pm I am very good at this part, but I would like to know how you find a melody for your chords.


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201902121559

2.12.19  3:59 pm   how do i find the best chords for my melody

     just find the harmonies 1 note at a time. go thorugh the entire song and add just 1 note to 1 moment. see if you can find that special moment that really needs it, and find out which note it needs. I'll give you one to get started. "Celebrate good times come on", that party song from the 70s. playing that vocal part all the way through, no band, no harmony, and i have to decide 1 moment to add 1 note. i'm gonna say for "come on", not the first but every 2nd and 4th time of "come on" in the choruses, let's add a maj 3rd above the voc melody. so if the song is in Ab, let's add the C note above "come on", not the first time but the second and 4th time it occurs in the choruses. ok now you pick a song, with just the melody, and pick what you think is the most important spot to add 1 note to. or if you want, you can find another one for the song i did

1.29.19  9:16 am   1.27.19  8:04 pm   what is your set up for this? how can i do that

     you can do it with your phone, but i use a smaller device called a 'digital voice recorder.' i can't say what brand it is but i've been using the same one since 2010 (and before that i was using a similar one.) if you search for digital voice recorders i think you will find the kind of device i am talking about. i've discovered the best thing is to put it in the small pocket on the sun visor. then i discovered that this actually vibrates sometimes, (unfortunately most recordings i have from 2015 have a lot of vibrations in them) but after doing the journal edits project (making the reality page) in 2016 i discovered that i could use a glove to cushion the recorder, and also place a folded sock between the visor and the ceiling. this fixed the problem. that was in my previous car, and my current car, the pocket was actually too tight to hold the voice recorder but after stretching it out a bit now it fits. and i don't think there are any vibration problems but who knows, maybe there are, and i will discover it when i do the next round of reality edits

1.10.19  4:40 pm   How did the 'La de da de da de da de day oh' song come to be? It sounds so good to me! It probably was similar to the process of other songs, but I'm asking because, in my opinion, it really stands out, and I want to know more about it.

     this may sound boring and technical but i wrote some of it on a writing session, then wrote a bit more of it on a writing session, and then finally wrote the remainder of the song during a writing session. that's the short story. the long story is, i was doing a writing session many many years ago after many years of not doing writing sessions. actually it felt like i had never done a writing session before, it had been so long. i know i did many years before that, but it seemed so far away and i'm not quite sure how i ever did it. too long ago to remember really, and the world had surely changed since then, mine and everyone else's. so i was doing something which i think might have been totally new, i was just writing. not in the recording thing, not trying to record and write at the same time, just writing. like on paper, and i had 1 instrument to play along to what i was singing, and weirdly it was an unplugged bass. which doesn't quite make sense but it was a quiet room and i was just using it to indicate chords. not play chords, but just play the bass notes to indicate chords. so a few things were written on that session, including a thing that looked like this. you may mostly recognize this verse, sort of mostly. but the chorus it goes to on this page (not shown) is completely different, and wraps up to a surprise twist ending very quickly, making it a probably less than 1 minute piece called, presumably, 'in the snow.' the snow not really being the chorus, the snow being the twist ending. so that's 'in the snow.' fast forward maybe 3 and a half years. i am getting my life togther and going through the stacks and stacks of writing sessions i've done over the years, and getting it all organized and doing writing on them, for days and days and days and days and weeks, a many months long writing-only period i call 'writing tare' when i worked only on writing for almost a year, and not starting any new ones, just updating/continuing/finishing/fixing on existing songs and fragments. very early on in this process, around september 2012, i took a look at 'in the snow,' made some small adjustments to the verse to make it stronger, the pre-chorus got changed from 'i'm gonna count to 3' to instead 'i'm gonna write a song'. therefore the old chorus didn't make sense (something about counting to 3 i assume) ditched it and wrote a brand new much brighter stronger chorus, which as you can see seems to be nearly exactly the la de da chorus. and then it sat there burning a hole in my shelf, as a ray of sunshine with a high standard i suppose i was afraid to live up to. fast forward to 2017, i've been actually recording songs, and videos of many different types, for many years at this point, and over the years the writing list had grown out of control, mostly from 2010 to 2013 but still even more later, so most of the time doing a song (recording + video) means going through the list and finding something i want to do. in post-hotewig i had made the decision to allow fragments to be picked (songs where only partial writing was done) so as to get something almost entirely new and finish the writing on the spot and record it. out of something like 400 to choose from, i manually got it down to about 41 finalists, planning to do a random number selection to choose. but i narrowed it down again manually to 27, and with agonizing fear i chose the number and it picked la de da. and then the next day i had terrible cold feet about it, thought it was lame and stupid. switched it to a slow song, switched it to another song, lost my mind, wasn't sure, and then somewhere around getting into the haircut chair (was planning on doing real video performance footage for this one) i was pondering a second verse after the bright la de da chorus, and the first 3 mall lines tumbled into my head quite readily. so at least that mostly solidified the song choice for me and gave it an extra push toward validity, and from there the decision was finalized and i quickly finished the writing and then went into production which took agonizingly long because it turns out going on camera in front of zillions of people can be scary if you haven't been doing it regularly

     Also, keep up the good work, I think 'Just did a bad thing' may be your best song yet.

     that is nice of you

writing session before, it had been so long. i know i did many years before that, but it seemed so far away and i'm not quite sure how i ever did it. too long ago to remember really, and the world had surely changed since then, mine and everyone else's. so i was doing something which i think might have been totally new, i was just writing. not in the recording thing, not trying to record and write at the same time, just writing. like on paper, and i had 1 instrument to play along to what i was singing, and weirdly it was an unplugged bass. which doesn't quite make sense but it was a quiet room and i was just using it to indicate chords. not play chords, but just play the bass notes to indicate chords. so a few things were written on that session, including a thing that looked like this. you may mostly recognize this verse, sort of mostly. but the chorus it goes to on this page (not shown) is completely different, and wraps up to a surprise twist ending very quickly, making it a probably less than 1 minute piece called, presumably, 'in the snow.' the snow not really being the chorus, the snow being the twist ending. so that's 'in the snow.' fast forward maybe 3 and a half years. i am getting my life togther and going through the stacks and stacks of writing sessions i've done over the years, and getting it all organized and doing writing on them, for days and days and days and days and weeks, a many months long writing-only period i call 'writing tare' when i worked only on writing for almost a year, and not starting any new ones, just updating/continuing/finishing/fixing on existing songs and fragments. very early on in this process, around september 2012, i took a look at 'in the snow,' made some small adjustments to the verse to make it stronger, the pre-chorus got changed from 'i'm gonna count to 3' to instead 'i'm gonna write a song'. therefore the old chorus didn't make sense (something about counting to 3 i assume) ditched it and wrote a brand new much brighter stronger chorus, which as you can see seems to be nearly exactly the la de da chorus. and then it sat there burning a hole in my shelf, as a ray of sunshine with a high standard i suppose i was afraid to live up to. fast forward to 2017, i've been actually recording songs, and videos of many different types, for many years at this point, and over the years the writing list had grown out of control, mostly from 2010 to 2013 but still even more later, so most of the time doing a song (recording + video) means going through the list and finding something i want to do. in post-hotewig i had made the decision to allow fragments to be picked (songs where only partial writing was done) so as to get something almost entirely new and finish the writing on the spot and record it. out of something like 400 to choose from, i manually got it down to about 41 finalists, planning to do a random number selection to choose. but i narrowed it down again manually to 27, and with agonizing fear i chose the number and it picked la de da. and then the next day i had terrible cold feet about it, thought it was lame and stupid. switched it to a slow song, switched it to another song, lost my mind, wasn't sure, and then somewhere around getting into the haircut chair (was planning on doing real video performance footage for this one) i was pondering a second verse after the bright la de da chorus, and the first 3 mall lines tumbled into my head quite readily. so at least that mostly solidified the song choice for me and gave it an extra push toward validity, and from there the decision was finalized and i quickly finished the writing and then went into production which took agonizingly long because it turns out going on camera in front of zillions of people can be scary if you haven't been doing it regularly

     Also, keep up the good work, I think 'Just did a bad thing' may be your best song yet.

     that is nice of you

1.12.19  5:45 pm   1.11.19  2:46 pm - Your answer sounds romantic but that's not the case.

      Most pop songs use the same I-V-vi-IV chord progression -

      there has to be something about this that is objectively more pleasing than other chord combinations to the human ear, else the same formula wouldn't work again and again as it does now to make hits. The number of combinations that achieve the same effect must be limited and there has to be a pattern to it. Isn't that what studying music is all about?
